trial_identification.scientifictitle: Applicability of CBT to Unselected Mental Health Service Clients With Psychotic Disorders

interventions.interventions:
Behaviour - Recovery Therapy (Cognitive Behaviour Therapy for psychosis)
Behaviour: Recovery Therapy (Cognitive Behaviour Therapy for psychosis)

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine the applicability of cognitive behaviour therapy for psychosis in the "real world" setting of ordinary mental health services

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To establish rates of uptake of Recovery Therapy amongst clients at a community mental health service
To establish effectiveness of therapy in clients who received a defined length of therapeutic contact (12-24 sessions)
To identify factors predicting uptake and effectiveness

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- acceptance by the participating Community Mental Health Services for case management
- a preliminary DSM-IV diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, mood disorder with psychotic features, or delusional disorder
- a recovery "need" in one of the areas addressed by the therapy
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- a preliminary DSM-IV diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, drug-induced psychosis, mood disorder without hallucinations or delusions, or any other disorder (eg. personality disorder, PTSD) even where psychotic features are/have been present
- non-English speaking
- comorbid intellectual disability

recruitment.hospital: Whittlesea Community Mental Health Service - Epping
Darebin Community Mental Health Service - Preston

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This project will systematically apply a specialist version of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT), known as Recovery Therapy, to a random sample of patients with psychotic disorders. Previously, the therapy has been developed and efficacy established, but the extent of applicability to (unselected) mental health service patients is unknown. The main aim is to establish the extent to which this therapy is acceptable and effective for mental health service clients. A secondary aim is to develop guidelines for the conduct of such therapy in public mental health settings.
